joebrummer

What kind of camera do you prefer...Real photographic film holders or initially digital graphic grabbers?

 Tough one.....I have both. My digital is a fugi S5000 and I love it. I get great shots and that is what is on my website www.joebrummer.com On the other hand, I have an old 1973 fujica SLR 35mm Film, with every lense known to man. I like having the lenses and depth of filed control, but on the other, other hand, I want a digital SLR, so I can change lenses and still do digital. Digital is better, sharper and more crisp. You know in seconds if you got the shot, you get sharper images and can remove any noise or grain. Digital all the way.

georged

What kind of camera do you prefer...Real photographic film holders or initially digital graphic grabbers?

 
 Digital, no question. I just went to digital SLR and it does everything my film SLR cameras did, only better. Plus no waiting for proofs then going to print, knowing immediately how shots turn out and being able to fiddle with exposure, clarity and contrast in minutes without lab step-up/down processes. And the pleasure of immediately posting to the web without scanning.
jim's trucking

Digital, no question. I just went to digital SLR and it does everything my film SLR cameras did, only better. Plus no waiting for proofs then going to print, knowing immediately how shots turn out and being able to fiddle with exposure, clarity and contrast in minutes without lab step-up/down processes. And the pleasure of immediately posting to the web without scanning. 
Plus, when you scan, you get a pixel file anyway...might as well start with one.

 Quote from reviews:
 
 ~The sensor technologies do have different needs to film, but I think the issue is the size of sensors and other techno-design issues, than the angle the light needs to hit ... if you think about it, the angle the light hits the sensor is exactly the same as if it hit film. It is just that the size of the sensor is different and thus (I assume) placed on a different plane to where film would be. 
 
 You can use all the Canon EF lenses (I use all mine, some of which I have had for a long time) on the 10D or even 1Ds and Ef and EF-S on the 300D/Rebel. You can use most (if not all) of the Nikkor lenses with the Nikon D70 or D100 or Kodak ~
 
 Other major players, including Canon, all have digital lens and flash lines for their digital SLRs. Even Soligar, one of the larger aftermarket lens manufacturers, is already out with new digital lens and flash products for the majors. While the sensor issue is debatable on other than low-end digital SLRs, most people I've spokem with prefer to use newer digital lenses than the smaller sensor film lenses. 
 
 I have a big bag of expensive Nikkor lenses collecting dust that, after going to digital SLR, I'll probably never again use. Pure consumerism, but I like digital SLR quality and convenience well enough that it doesn't bother me. I'll just store them with old tax records so I don't have to look at them.

Well thanks guys, I am glad to see these links. Two years ago I took my AE1 over at the largest camera store around , and I told the owner I wanted a new camera, but wanted my collection of lens to work on the new camera...
 
 He told me that no way would my lens work on any of his cameras, and that I would need to buy a new camera , and all new lens that would fit it. I thanked him and left empty handed. It looks like things have changed since then.

Duo_Maxwell

Argh. I can't remember which is which.
 
 One is generally better for outdoors and one is generally better for indoors. 
 
 As for sports, especially the fast ones, I'd go with film. Digital takes too long to record 8 fps.
GreenMtnBoy

Digital is better for quick easy shots where you don't need great quality. Costs less and more user friendly.
 
 Film is better for the semi-serious or serious photographer. As long as you know what your doing, you will always get a better shot with film than digital. Yes it's more expensive, and you have to take afew shots to make sure you got it right, but digital will never surpass the quality of film. Never.
 
 
Digital is better, sharper and more crisp.... you get sharper images and can remove any noise or grain.

 
 Are you on crack?
Spad

Shot film since the '60s. Bought a P&S digital about 5 years ago. Bought a Canon DRebel a year and a half ago. Film is dead. 6mp is good for up to 11x14, same as 35mm. The new one is 8mp and even better.
Spazee Magee

If I am shooting pictures of sports I like to use film because its got a faster shutter and every thing doesn't come out as a big blur.
 
 I like film for still life. I prefer digital becaus I can take the pic then put it on my computer with adobe CS wich I recomend to every one because you can do every thing and a little bit more. I also like digital because it is so cheap.

chemist99a

I guess I'm just a purist, I'd have to say film. Not that I don't appreciate the advantages of digital, there's just something about film. It's probably mostly developing film. That's where all the fun and the art is.

 
 I agree the digital world as marvelous as it is is very different from doing it with film. Frankly its just too darn easy with digital. I always loved dark room work, and monochrome images. Marvelous control and one needs both chemical skills and manual dexterity. Oh well I am stuck with digital because its fast, convenient and does allow creativity. Miss the old days though when I did lots of portraiture on 4X5 format film and made large prints.
Ravin

I'm a purist as well. I like regualr old film-and-darkrooms. I've also had a bad experience with digital - my wife got a digital camera and took numerous pictures on a vacation out west (driving vacation) while my own film camera was in the repair shop. When we got back, she turned the camera on once more, and: nothing. The memory chip doohickey was apparently "corrupted", and over 200 pictures were lost just like that (we tried every conceivable recovery, taking it to professionals, etc., and managed to get ten pictures back)
Master_Shake

I'd take a photo class if I had the money to invest in a decent camera. My dad used to be a photographer, so I want to take a class for the purpose of having access to a darkroom more than anything else lol
jim's trucking

I'd take a photo class if I had the money to invest in a decent camera. My dad used to be a photographer, so I want to take a class for the purpose of having access to a darkroom more than anything else lol
That is fun. I was in the Photography Club in High School...had a nice dark room and enlarger...spent many hours playing with darkroom exposures (after the negatives were processed). It is absolutely amazing what can be done with real light and your own imagination.
 
 Even the 35mm work was fun...the 4x4 was awesome.
 
 You wouldn't need a high cost camera to get into it...just one with a good lens or two. The darkroom work was more enjoyable to me than the camera work because it revealed the results in a magical sort of way...and you can make many changes to the outcome by shading the light from the enlarger during exposure.
 
 Take the leap...get into it.
Master_Shake

Definitely both. 
 
 If you'd like a camera that's basically as good as film, and even has the same old body-style, but uses digital, check out the Nikon D80.
 
 I have one and it blew me away when I first started using it - quite amazing. You can also take a bunch of pictures in just a few seconds - perfect if you're trying to capture something that is moving and aren't sure if you got the right shot, etc.

The Barbarian

My antiques are mosting the folding bellows kind that were popular in the early 1900's. My prize camera is a late 1800's wet plate studio camera.
 

 
 Did you know that you can still get rollfilm for most of those obsolete formats?
JPSartre12

Did you know that you can still get rollfilm for most of those obsolete formats?

 
 Where? I'd like to try a few out.
The Barbarian

B&H has a number of old formats available.
 
 110, 127, 620 & 828 Film | B&H Photo Video
 
 Your wetplate studio camera can be converted to cutfilm holders, possibly with no modification at all, if you're lucky enough to have one that can take the backs.
 
 Often, a camera made for 620 will take 120 rollfilm; the difference in spool diameter is quite small, and some 120 spools will fit in some 620 cameras. If not, get a changing bag, buy a few 620 spools and roll your own. 120 film is the same as 620; only the spools are different. Of course, you'll need a finisher who understand you need the spools back, or you can develop your own.
 
 Apparently, a few manufacturers still make 127 rollfilm, and there are some amazing little 127 cameras out there for not much money. Yashica made a cute and pretty good twin lens reflex for 127.
Peeling

If I am shooting pictures of sports I like to use film because its got a faster shutter and every thing doesn't come out as a big blur.

 Really? That's exactly the reverse of my experience. I can stick my wife's D700 on ISO3200 and enjoy high shutter speeds in terrible light at a quality surpassing anything ISO3200 film (or even ISO800 for that matter) could produce. At 8FPS too, if I shove some AA batteries in the grip.
